Editing and Using User-Defined Functions 


 Functions are defined by first clicking EDIT_F button, which shows a dialog where users can pick one of six functions (f0 to f5) to edit. Clicking one of the functions will change the calculator to edit mode where text above the expression input will change to Editing f$: to remind the user they are in edit-mode. Entering edit mode will keep the previous mathematical expression unless it contains a user-defined function or ANS, as these cannot be used in user-defined functions Functions are inputted with the same scientific keyboard as before, but with four new buttons that appear in edit mode: x, y, z, and SAVE_F 


 The function inputted can have between 0 and 3 variables. x, y, and z are the three variables that can be used in the functions. A function with 0 variables would be simply entering a mathematical expression as the function (e.g. 3 or cos(45) ), while a function with 3 variables would include x, y, and z. Functions are saved by clicking the SAVE_F button or the = button. The user will receive a message "Edited f$!" (where $ is replaced with 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5), which means that the function was successfully edited and saved. Edit-mode is automatically exited. 


 Functions can be saved even if they are incorrect, but some processing takes place to ensure the functions behave as expected. Notably, if a single-variable equation was entered, the single-variable is always saved as x (even if only y or z was used). For a double-variable equation, this is always saved as using x and y (f(y,z) and f(x,z) would both be saved as f(x,y)). Variables are always shifted backwards towards the start of the alphabet (e.g. the ys in f(y,z) would become xs and the zs would become ys). 


 Functions are called by pressing the USE_F button and clicking which function to use. Function arguments are separated using the comma button, and they always correspond to the variables in alphabetical order (e.g. f0(), f0(x), f0(x,y) or f0(x,y,z) if f0 was selected). Supplying the wrong number of function arguments will return an Input Error message. Note that multiple user-defined functions can be used in one mathematical expression, and an argument of a user-defined function can even be a user-defined function. 


 For more information, the full user manual is available at:
https://gitlab.cecs.anu.edu.au/u6999534/gp19s2/wikis/App-Summary-and-Manual
